009package squidpony.squidmath;
010
011import squidpony.StringKit;
012
013import java.io.Serializable;
014
015/**
016 * This is a SplittableRandom-style generator, meant to have a tiny state
017 * that permits storing many different generators with low overhead.
018 * It should be rather fast, though no guarantees can be made on all hardware.
019 * It should be faster than using SplittableRandom from Java 8 because it has a
020 * single "gamma" value that prevents it from being split but also makes runtime
021 * a bit quicker. It is based on using a unary hash on a large-increment counter,
022 * which makes even the first item obtained from similarly-seeded LightRNGs very
023 * likely to be very different. This is an advantage over non-hash-based RNGs.
024 * <br>
025 * This generator is especially fast on OpenJ9, version 0.17.0 or later (from
026 * late 2019), and can be several times faster there than on HotSpot.
027 * <br>
028 * Written in 2015 by Sebastiano Vigna (vigna@acm.org)
029 * @author Sebastiano Vigna
030 * @author Tommy Ettinger
031 */
032public final class LightRNG implements RandomnessSource, StatefulRandomness, SkippingRandomness, Serializable
033{
034        private static final long serialVersionUID = -374415589203474497L;
035
036    public long state; /* The state can be seeded with any value. */
037
038    /** Creates a new generator seeded using Math.random. */
039    public LightRNG() {
040        this((long) ((Math.random() - 0.5) * 0x10000000000000L)
041                ^ (long) (((Math.random() - 0.5) * 2.0) * 0x8000000000000000L));
042    }
043
044    public LightRNG( final long seed ) {
045        setSeed(seed);
046    }
047
048    /**
049     * Gets a pseudo-random int with at most the specified count of bits; for example, if bits is 3 this can return any
050     * int between 0 and 2 to the 3 (that is, 8), exclusive on the upper end. That would mean 7 could be returned, but
051     * no higher ints, and 0 could be returned, but no lower ints.
052     * 
053     * The algorithm used here changed on March 8, 2018 when LightRNG was remade the default generator in SquidLib.
054     * The older method is available as {@link #compatibleNext(int)}, but its use is discouraged; it's slightly slower 
055     * for no good reason.
056     * @param bits the number of bits to be returned; if 0 or less, or if 32 or greater, can return any 32-bit int
057     * @return a pseudo-random int that uses at most the specified amount of bits
058     */
059    @Override
060    public final int next( int bits ) {
061        long z = state += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
062        z = (z ^ (z >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
063        z = (z ^ (z >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
064        return (int)(z ^ (z >>> 31)) >>> (32 - bits);
065    }
066    /**
067     * Gets a pseudo-random int with at most the specified count of bits; for example, if bits is 3 this can return any
068     * int between 0 and 2 to the 3 (that is, 8), exclusive on the upper end. That would mean 7 could be returned, but
069     * no higher ints, and 0 could be returned, but no lower ints.
070     *
071     * The algorithm used here is the older version of {@link #next(int)} before some things changed on March 8 2018.
072     * Using this method is discouraged unless you need to reproduce values exactly; it's slightly slower for no good
073     * reason. Calling {@code next(32)} and {@code compatibleNext(32)} should have identical results, but other values
074     * for bits will probably be different.
075     * @param bits the number of bits to be returned; if 0 or less, or if 32 or greater, can return any 32-bit int
076     * @return a pseudo-random int that uses at most the specified amount of bits
077     */
078    public final int compatibleNext( int bits ) {
079        long z = state += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
080        z = (z ^ (z >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
081        z = (z ^ (z >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
082        return (int)( (z ^ (z >>> 31)) & ( 1L << bits ) - 1 );
083    }
084    /**
085     * Can return any long, positive or negative, of any size permissible in a 64-bit signed integer.
086     * @return any long, all 64 bits are random
087     */
088    @Override
089    public final long nextLong() {
090        long z = state += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
091        z = (z ^ (z >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
092        z = (z ^ (z >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
093        return z ^ (z >>> 31);
094    }
095
096    /**
097     * Produces a copy of this RandomnessSource that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the
098     * copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called. This just needs to
099     * copy the state so it isn't shared, usually, and produce a new value with the same exact state.
100     *
101     * @return a copy of this RandomnessSource
102     */
103    @Override
104    public LightRNG copy() {
105        return new LightRNG(state);
106    }
107
108    /**
109     * Can return any int, positive or negative, of any size permissible in a 32-bit signed integer.
110     * @return any int, all 32 bits are random
111     */
112    public int nextInt() {
113        long z = state += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
114        z = (z ^ (z >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
115        z = (z ^ (z >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
116        return (int) (z ^ (z >>> 31)); 
117    }
118
119    /**
120     * Returns a random non-negative integer between 0 (inclusive) and the given bound (exclusive),
121     * or 0 if the bound is 0. 
122     * The bound should not be negative; use {@link IRNG#nextSignedInt(int)} if you need a negative outer bound.
123     * Uses an aggressively optimized technique that has some bias, but mostly for values of
124     * bound over 1 billion. This method uses the same technique as {@link RNG#nextIntHasty(int)},
125     * and like that method will always advance state exactly once (equivalent to one call to
126     * {@link #nextLong()}).
127     * <br>
128     * Credit goes to Daniel Lemire, http://lemire.me/blog/2016/06/27/a-fast-alternative-to-the-modulo-reduction/
129     *
130     * @param bound the outer bound (exclusive), should be positive
131     * @return the found number
132     */
133    public int nextInt( final int bound ) {
134        long z = state += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
135        z = (z ^ (z >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
136        z = (z ^ (z >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
137        return (int) ((bound * ((z ^ (z >>> 31)) & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31);
138    }
139
140    /**
141     * Like {@link #compatibleNext(int)}, but for compatibility with {@link #nextInt(int)}.
142     * Exclusive on the upper bound.  The lower bound is 0.
143     * @param bound the upper bound; should be positive
144     * @return a random int less than n and at least equal to 0
145     */
146    public int compatibleNextInt( final int bound ) {
147        if (bound <= 0) return 0;
148        int threshold = (0x7fffffff - bound + 1) % bound;
149        for (; ; ) {
150            int bits = (int) (nextLong() & 0x7fffffff);
151            if (bits >= threshold)
152                return bits % bound;
153        }
154    }
155    /**
156     * Inclusive lower, exclusive upper. Although you should usually use a higher value for upper than for lower, you
157     * can use a lower "upper" than "lower" and this will still work, producing an int between the two bounds.
158     * @param lower the lower bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
159     * @param upper the upper bound, exclusive, can be positive or negative, should be greater than lower
160     * @return a random int between lower (inclusive) and upper (exclusive)
161     */
162    public int nextInt( final int lower, final int upper ) {
163        return lower + nextInt(upper - lower);
164    }
165
166    /**
167     * Inclusive lower, exclusive upper.
168     * @param lower the lower bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
169     * @param upper the upper bound, exclusive, should be positive, must be greater than lower
170     * @return a random int between lower (inclusive) and upper (exclusive)
171     */
172    public int compatibleNextInt( final int lower, final int upper ) {
173        if ( upper - lower <= 0 ) throw new IllegalArgumentException("Upper bound must be greater than lower bound");
174        return lower + compatibleNextInt(upper - lower);
175    }
176
177    /**
178     * Exclusive on the outer bound; the inner bound is 0. The bound may be negative, which will produce a non-positive
179     * result.
180     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be positive or negative
181     * @return a random long between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive)
182     */
183    public long nextLong(long bound) {
184        long rand = nextLong();
185        final long randLow = rand & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
186        final long boundLow = bound & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
187        rand >>>= 32;
188        bound >>= 32;
189        final long t = rand * boundLow + (randLow * boundLow >>> 32);
190        return rand * bound + (t >> 32) + (randLow * bound + (t & 0xFFFFFFFFL) >> 32);
191    }
192    
193    /**
194     * Inclusive inner, exclusive outer; both inner and outer can be positive or negative.
195     * @param inner the inner bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
196     * @param outer the outer bound, exclusive, can be positive or negative and may be greater than or less than inner
197     * @return a random long that may be equal to inner and will otherwise be between inner and outer
198     */
199    public long nextLong(final long inner, final long outer) {
200        return inner + nextLong(outer - inner);
201    }
202
203
204    /**
205     * Exclusive on the upper bound. The lower bound is 0. Unlike {@link #nextInt(int)} or {@link #nextLong(long)}, this
206     * may sometimes advance the state more than once, depending on what numbers are produced internally and the bound.
207     * {@link #nextLong(long)} is preferred because it is much faster and reliably advances the state only once. Because
208     * this method uses rejection sampling, getting multiple random longs to "smooth the odds" when the bound is such
209     * that it can't fairly distribute one random long across all possible outcomes, it may be more "fair" than
210     * {@link #nextLong(long)}, though it could potentially consume more of the period faster if pathologically bad
211     * bounds were used very often, and if enough of the period is gone then statistical flaws may become detectable.
212     * @param bound the upper bound; if this isn't positive, this method always returns 0
213     * @return a random long less than n and at least equal to 0
214     */
215    public long compatibleNextLong(final long bound) {
216        if ( bound <= 0 ) return 0;
217        long threshold = (0x7fffffffffffffffL - bound + 1) % bound;
218        for (;;) {
219            long bits = nextLong() & 0x7fffffffffffffffL;
220            if (bits >= threshold)
221                return bits % bound;
222        }
223    }
224
225    /**
226     * Inclusive lower, exclusive upper.
227     * @param lower the lower bound, inclusive, can be positive or negative
228     * @param upper the upper bound, exclusive, should be positive, must be greater than lower
229     * @return a random long at least equal to lower and less than upper
230     */
231    public long compatibleNextLong( final long lower, final long upper ) {
232        if ( upper - lower <= 0 )  throw new IllegalArgumentException("Upper bound must be greater than lower bound");
233        return lower + compatibleNextLong(upper - lower);
234    }
235    /**
236     * Gets a uniform random double in the range [0.0,1.0)
237     * @return a random double at least equal to 0.0 and less than 1.0
238     */
239    public double nextDouble() {
240        long z = state += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
241        z = (z ^ (z >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
242        z = (z ^ (z >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
243        return ((z ^ (z >>> 31)) & 0x1fffffffffffffL) * 0x1p-53;
244    }
245
246    /**
247     * Gets a uniform random double in the range [0.0,outer) given a positive parameter outer. If outer
248     * is negative, it will be the (exclusive) lower bound and 0.0 will be the (inclusive) upper bound.
249     * @param outer the exclusive outer bound, can be negative
250     * @return a random double between 0.0 (inclusive) and outer (exclusive)
251     */
252    public double nextDouble(final double outer) {
253        return nextDouble() * outer;
254    }
255
256    /**
257     * Gets a uniform random float in the range [0.0,1.0)
258     * @return a random float at least equal to 0.0 and less than 1.0
259     */
260    public float nextFloat() {
261        long z = state += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
262        z = (z ^ (z >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
263        z = (z ^ (z >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
264        return ((z ^ (z >>> 31)) & 0xffffffL) * 0x1p-24f;
265
266    }
267
268    /**
269     * Gets a random value, true or false.
270     * Calls nextLong() once.
271     * @return a random true or false value.
272     */
273    public boolean nextBoolean() {
274        return nextLong() < 0L;
275    }
276
277    /**
278     * Given a byte array as a parameter, this will fill the array with random bytes (modifying it
279     * in-place). Calls nextLong() {@code Math.ceil(bytes.length / 8.0)} times.
280     * @param bytes a byte array that will have its contents overwritten with random bytes.
281     */
282    public void nextBytes( final byte[] bytes ) {
283        int i = bytes.length, n;
284        while( i != 0 ) {
285            n = Math.min( i, 8 );
286            for ( long bits = nextLong(); n-- != 0; bits >>>= 8 ) bytes[ --i ] = (byte)bits;
287        }
288    }
289
290
291
292    /**
293     * Sets the seed of this generator (which is also the current state).
294     * @param seed the seed to use for this LightRNG, as if it was constructed with this seed.
295     */
296    public void setSeed( final long seed ) {
297        state = seed;
298    }
299    /**
300     * Sets the seed (also the current state) of this generator.
301     * @param seed the seed to use for this LightRNG, as if it was constructed with this seed.
302     */
303    @Override
304    public void setState( final long seed ) {
305        state = seed;
306    }
307    /**
308     * Gets the current state of this generator.
309     * @return the current seed of this LightRNG, changed once per call to nextLong()
310     */
311    @Override
312    public long getState() {
313        return state;
314    }
315
316    /**
317     * Advances or rolls back the LightRNG's state without actually generating each number. Skips forward
318     * or backward a number of steps specified by advance, where a step is equal to one call to nextLong(),
319     * and returns the random number produced at that step (you can get the state with {@link #getState()}).
320     *
321     * @param advance Number of future generations to skip over; can be negative to backtrack, 0 gets the most recent generated number
322     * @return the random long generated after skipping advance numbers
323     */
324    @Override
325    public long skip(long advance) {
326        long z = (state += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L * advance);
327        z = (z ^ (z >>> 30)) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
328        z = (z ^ (z >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
329        return z ^ (z >>> 31);
330    }
331
332
333    @Override
334    public String toString() {
335        return "LightRNG with state 0x" + StringKit.hex(state) + 'L';
336    }
337
338    @Override
339    public boolean equals(Object o) {
340        if (this == o) return true;
341        if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
342
343        LightRNG lightRNG = (LightRNG) o;
344
345        return state == lightRNG.state;
346    }
347
348    @Override
349    public int hashCode() {
350        return (int) (state ^ (state >>> 32));
351    }
352
353    public static long determine(long state)
354    {
355        return ((state = ((state = ((state *= 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) ^ state >>> 30) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L) ^ state >>> 27) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL) ^ state >>> 31);
356    }
357    public static long determine(final int a, final int b)
358    {
359        long state = 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L + (a & 0xFFFFFFFFL) + ((long)b << 32);
360        state = ((state >>> 30) ^ state) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L;
361        state = (state ^ (state >>> 27)) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL;
362        return state ^ (state >>> 31);
363    }
364
365    public static int determineBounded(long state, int bound)
366    {
367        return (bound = (int)((bound * (((state = ((state = ((state *= 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) ^ state >>> 30) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L) ^ state >>> 27) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL) ^ state >>> 31) & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31)) + (bound >>> 31);
368    }
369
370    /**
371     * Returns a random float that is deterministic based on state; if state is the same on two calls to this, this will
372     * return the same float. This is expected to be called with a changing variable, e.g. {@code determine(++state)},
373     * where the increment for state should be odd but otherwise doesn't really matter. This multiplies state by
374     * {@code 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L} within this method, so using a small increment won't be much different from using a
375     * very large one, as long as it is odd. The period is 2 to the 64 if you increment or decrement by 1, but there are
376     * only 2 to the 30 possible floats between 0 and 1.
377     * @param state a variable that should be different every time you want a different random result;
378     *              using {@code determine(++state)} is recommended to go forwards or {@code determine(--state)} to
379     *              generate numbers in reverse order
380     * @return a pseudo-random float between 0f (inclusive) and 1f (exclusive), determined by {@code state}
381     */
382    public static float determineFloat(long state) { return (((state = ((state = ((state *= 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) ^ state >>> 30) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L) ^ state >>> 27) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL) ^ state >>> 31) & 0xFFFFFF) * 0x1p-24f; }
383
384    /**
385     * Returns a random double that is deterministic based on state; if state is the same on two calls to this, this
386     * will return the same float. This is expected to be called with a changing variable, e.g.
387     * {@code determine(++state)}, where the increment for state should be odd but otherwise doesn't really matter. This
388     * multiplies state by {@code 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L} within this method, so using a small increment won't be much
389     * different from using a very large one, as long as it is odd. The period is 2 to the 64 if you increment or
390     * decrement by 1, but there are only 2 to the 62 possible doubles between 0 and 1.
391     * @param state a variable that should be different every time you want a different random result;
392     *              using {@code determine(++state)} is recommended to go forwards or {@code determine(--state)} to
393     *              generate numbers in reverse order
394     * @return a pseudo-random double between 0.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive), determined by {@code state}
395     */
396    public static double determineDouble(long state) { return (((state = ((state = ((state *= 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L) ^ state >>> 30) * 0xBF58476D1CE4E5B9L) ^ state >>> 27) * 0x94D049BB133111EBL) ^ state >>> 31) & 0x1FFFFFFFFFFFFFL) * 0x1p-53; }
397}
